I'm not sure if this matters or not but... consider this:

If two optimal tic tac toe players play each other, what happens every
single time? a draw. Tic tac toe is inherently a game that as long as
both players have sufficient skill, the game will always end in a
draw.

Considering that...

Should the scoring be different?

If a player loses even one game, it means it is suboptimal.

Just wondering if considering the nature of the game would help...

So... I'm wondering if reconsidering the evaluation part would solve the issue.



On Tue, Aug 17, 2010 at 6:22 PM, Wesley Tansey <tansey@...> wrote:
> Anthony,
>
> Thanks for the kind words. :)
>
> There is at least one more tutorial coming. I have the HyperNEAT code
> implemented, it's actually very simple. The problem is that even the
> HyperNEAT Tic-Tac-Toe player still sucks, and I was kind of implicitly
> promising a near-optimal player next. It's funny how sometimes simple
> domains turn out to be so difficult. If I don't come up with anything in
> a few days, I'll write it up anyway.
>
> I'd be happy to hear suggestions from the group on better ways to
> coevolve a better player. I've been toying around with dual populations
> where one is O and the other is X, similar to the host-parasite setup I
> posted at the end of part 2, but no luck so far. The only other ideas I
> have left are to drastically increase the population size or to add in
> an optimal opponent with random noise like Fogel did originally. I
> hesitate to do the latter though, as coevolution is generally a more
> elegant solution.
>
> Sincerely,
